qas.question: Though harboring transitive properties, what Koppen climate classification does the New Haven climate more closely characterize?
What season is typically characterized as humid and warm in New Haven?
What baseline temperature threshold do temperatures normally exceed throughout the summer in New Haven?
How heavy is the snowfall typically throughout the winter in New Haven?
New Haven's climate is largely analogous to what major adjoining metropolitan area?
The New Haven's area closesly resemble which type of climate?
Does summertime gets weather hotter than 90 degrees?
Due to being a coastal city, how much snow does the city gets?
What is the main effects  in New Haven's weather due to being a coastal city?

context: New Haven lies in the transition between a <a5_0>humid continental climate<a5_0/> (Köppen climate classification: <a0_0>Dfa<a0_0/>) and humid subtropical climate (Köppen Cfa), but having more characteristics of the former, as is typical of much of the <a4_0>New York<a4_0/> metropolitan area. <a1_0>Summers<a1_0/> are humid and warm, with temperatures exceeding <a2_0>90 °F (32 °C)<a2_0/> on <a6_0>7–8 days per year<a6_0/>. Winters are cold with <a3_0><a7_0>moderate<a3_0/> snowfall<a7_0/> interspersed with rainfall and occasionally mixed precipitation. The weather patterns that affect New Haven result from a primarily offshore direction, thus reducing the marine influence of Long Island Sound—although, like other marine areas, <a8_0>differences in temperature between areas<a8_0/> right along the coastline and areas a mile or two inland can be large at times.
